Title: Organization of direct hippocampal efferent projections to the cerebral cortex of the rhesus monkey: Projections from CA1, prosubiculum, and subiculum to the temporal lobe
Abstract: This study investigates direct hippocampal efferent projections to the temporal lobe of the rhesus monkey. Tritiated amino acid injections were placed into the hippocampal formation to identify terminal fields, and complementary fluorescent retrograde tracer injections were placed into the cortex to identify the cells of origin. Tritiated amino acid injections into CA1, prosubicular, or subicular subfields produced anterograde label over parts of the parahippocampal gyrus and temporal pole. Injections of fluorescent retrograde tracers demonstrated that these projections originate from longitudinal strips of neurons that occupy part of the CA1 subfield as well as from strips of neurons in adjacent prosubicular and subicular subfields. Thus, an injection into area TH of the posterior parahippocampal gyrus labeled neurons in a longitudinal strip of proximal CA1 (i.e., near CA2) as well as a strip in the subiculum; injections into areas TF, TL, 35, or Pro labeled neurons in a longitudinal strip of distal CA1 (i.e., near the prosubiculum) as well as one in the prosubiculum; and an injection into area TFO labeled neurons in a longitudinal strip in the middle of CA1. These strips of neurons extended longitudinally throughout the entire rostrocaudal length of the hippocampus. These results demonstrate that, in the monkey, CA1 projections to cortex arise topographically from longitudinally oriented strips of neurons that occupy only a part of the transverse extent of CA1 but that cover most of the anteroposterior extent of the hippocampus. Thus, in the monkey, CA1 is not a single uniform entity and may have a unique role as a source of direct hippocampal projections to the cerebral cortex.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is nowhere mentioned, from which parcellation scheme areas 17-19 are adopted from. Both VV19 and B09 are possible, but B09 is more probable, because (i) B09 unlike VV19 did not subdivide area 19 and (ii) B09 has been already cited in contrast to VV19.

It is nowhere mentioned, from which parcellation scheme areas 17-19 are adopted from. Both VV19 and B09 are possible, but B09 is more probable, because (i) B09 unlike VV19 did not subdivide area 19 and (ii) B09 has been already cited in contrast to VV19.

It is nowhere mentioned, from which parcellation scheme areas 17-19 are adopted from. Both VV19 and B09 are possible, but B09 is more probable, because (i) B09 unlike VV19 did not subdivide area 19 and (ii) B09 has been already cited in contrast to VV19.

It is nowhere mentioned, from which parcellation scheme area 28 is adopted, but it seems that BR98 refer to B09, because (i) area 28 of B09 is a classic cited area for the description of the entorhinal cortex and (ii) B09 has been already cited in this paper.

It is not unambiguous, from which parcellation scheme areas TS1-3 of BR98 are adopted. But it is quite possible that BR98 refers to PS73, because (i) the areas have the same names, (ii) PS73 has been already cited in this paper , and (iii) PS73's parcellation scheme is a classic one for the description of the superior temporal gyrus and supratemporal plane respectively.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The neocortex of the inferotemporal area has a thicker layer IV than any adjacent areas of the anterior PHG (TLr) or posterior PHG (TF; Fig. 1A-C) and consists entirely of area TE of von Bonin and Bailey (1947). Area TE has been further subdivided into many areas, including TE1, TE2, TE3, TEA, TEM, and TEO, based on myeloarchitecture, cytoarchitecture, cortical inputs (for review, see Pandya and Yeterian, 1985) and physiology (see, e.g., Bayliss et al., 1987) " (p. 97)

"The cortex between the presubiculum and the occipitotemporal sulcus was divided into areas TH and TF by von Bonin and Bailey (1947) ... Between these areas, there is a distinctly different cortex that was not recognized by von Bonin and Bailey that has an incipient layer IV and a strong layer V but little separation between layers II and III or within layer V. In keeping with the style of von Bonin and Bailey we have designated this cortex as area TL ( Rosene and Pandya, 1983; Pandya et al., 1988; Demeter et al., 1990; Barnes and Pandya, 1992; Schmahmann and Pandya, 1992, 1993). This reflects the fact that it is an independent temporal lobe with distinct connections with the limbic system. Amaral et al. (1987) apparently recognized some aspects of this area, because they designated part of this as a caudal extension of Brodmann's area 36 back between TF and TH but did not recognize or illustrate its full extent. Caudally, these cytoarchitectonic areas (TH, TL, and TF) become modified before they are replaced by area OA (area 19). The most striking feature of this modification is the appearance of a crisp layer IV, even as the other features of layers II/III and V/VI remain constant. Therefore, as indicated on Figure 1D, we have designated these areas THO, TLO, and TFO ( Pandya et al., 1988) ... Lateral to the rhinal sulcus , there are two proisocortical areas, area 35 in the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus and a more lateral area that Amaral et al. (1987) have designated area 36 after Brodmann (1909), who limited this"entorhinal" area to the immediate bank of the rhinal sulcus but that Amaral et al. have extended out onto the ventral temporal lobe. Based on both connections and cytoarchitecture, we think that this bears more similarity to our area TL of the posterior PHG and have designated it as TLr (Rosene and Pandya, 1983; Pandya et al., 1988) and designated the caudal extension of it between TH and TF as TLc." (pp. 95, 97)

Area ReIt of BR98 means "retroinsular parietotemporal cortex" (p. 93), whereas areas ReIt and ReIpt of PS73 means "retroinsular temporal cortex" and "retroinsular parietal cortex" respectively. "The cortex between the presubiculum and the occipitotemporal sulcus was divided into areas TH and TF by von Bonin and Bailey (1947) ... Between these areas, there is a distinctly different cortex that was not recognized by von Bonin and Bailey that has an incipient layer IV and a strong layer V but little separation between layers II and III or within layer V. In keeping with the style of von Bonin and Bailey we have designated this cortex as area TL ( Rosene and Pandya, 1983; Pandya et al., 1988; Demeter et al., 1990; Barnes and Pandya, 1992; Schmahmann and Pandya, 1992, 1993). This reflects the fact that it is an independent temporal lobe with distinct connections with the limbic system. Amaral et al. (1987) apparently recognized some aspects of this area, because they designated part of this as a caudal extension of Brodmann's area 36 back between TF and TH but did not recognize or illustrate its full extent. Caudally, these cytoarchitectonic areas (TH, TL, and TF) become modified before they are replaced by area OA (area 19). The most striking feature of this modification is the appearance of a crisp layer IV, even as the other features of layers II/III and V/VI remain constant. Therefore, as indicated on Figure 1D, we have designated these areas THO, TLO, and TFO ( Pandya et al., 1988) ... Lateral to the rhinal sulcus , there are two proisocortical areas, area 35 in the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus and a more lateral area that Amaral et al. (1987) have designated area 36 after Brodmann (1909), who limited this"entorhinal" area to the immediate bank of the rhinal sulcus but that Amaral et al. have extended out onto the ventral temporal lobe. Based on both connections and cytoarchitecture, we think that this bears more similarity to our area TL of the posterior PHG and have designated it as TLr (Rosene and Pandya, 1983; Pandya et al., 1988) and designated the caudal extension of it between TH and TF as TLc." (pp. 95, 97)

(1987) apparently recognized some aspects of this area, because they designated part of this as a caudal extension of Brodmann's area 36 back between TF and TH but did not recognize or illustrate its full extent. Caudally, these cytoarchitectonic areas (TH, TL, and TF) become modified before they are replaced by area OA (area 19). The most striking feature of this modification is the appearance of a crisp layer IV, even as the other features of layers II/III and V/VI remain constant. Therefore, as indicated on Figure 1D, we have designated these areas THO, TLO, and TFO ( Pandya et al., 1988) ... Lateral to the rhinal sulcus , there are two proisocortical areas, area 35 in the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus and a more lateral area that Amaral et al. (1987) have designated area 36 after Brodmann (1909), who limited this"entorhinal" area to the immediate bank of the rhinal sulcus but that Amaral et al. have extended out onto the ventral temporal lobe. Based on both connections and cytoarchitecture, we think that this bears more similarity to our area TL of the posterior PHG and have designated it as TLr (Rosene and Pandya, 1983; Pandya et al., 1988) and designated the caudal extension of it between TH and TF as TLc." (pp. 95, 97)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: Area KaL of BR98 seems to be identical with area Kal of PS73, because (i) they have both the same abbreviation and (ii) PS73 has been already cited in this paper.
Area KaM of BR98 seems to be identical with area KaL of PS73, because (i) they have both the same abbreviation and (ii) PS73 has been already cited in this paper.

Area ReIt of BR98 means "retroinsular parietotemporal cortex" (p. 93), whereas areas ReIt and ReIpt of PS73 means "retroinsular temporal cortex" and "retroinsular parietal cortex" respectively. Although the abbreviation "ReIt" is the same both in BR98 and PS73, it seems that both areas are not identical, because the full name of these areas suggests us that the parietotemporal area ReIt of BR98 includes both parietal area ReIpt and temporal area ReIt of PS73.

It is not explicitly stated from which parcellation scheme area PaAc of BR98 is adopted, but it seems to be identical with area PaAc of PS73, because (i) they have same name, (ii) the same location , (iii) PS73 with it's map is classic for description of this part of the cortex, and (iv) it has been already cited in this paper.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Corrected_Why: BR98-Pro: "Farther rostral on the temporal pole area, TLr is bounded laterally by another proisocortex, designated Pro (Pandya and Sanides, 1973; Galaburda and Pandya, 1983)." But the Pro regions in these two references are different: the GP83 pro extends beyond the STS. From Fig 2 in BR98 it appears that their Pro also extends, so it is not equal to PS73-Pro.

@Methods.Comments:
Citation: " Based on the distribution of amino acids labelling, in an additional five monkeys, 19 injections of fluorescent retrograde tracers ( FRT`s ) were made into different parts of the temporal lobe to determine the exact cells of origin of hippocampal projections to these regions.
Three monkeys each received unilateral injections of three FRT`s: Diamidino Yellow ( DY ), fast blue ( FB ), and rhodamine-labelled latex beads ( RB ) in different sites in the temporal lobe.
One monkey ( PGF-L ) receivedfour tracer injections into one hemisphere, the fourth being fluorescein-labelled, green, fluorescent latex beads ( GB ).
The fifth monkey ( case PET ) received injections of three FRT`s into each hemisphere after transection of the corpus callosum ( except the rostrum ), dorsal hippocampal commissure, and anterior commissure. " ( p. 94 )

" ...  as illustrated in case PET-R (Fig. 8D). In this case, an injection was of FB was centered in area TF in the medial bank of the occipitotemporal sulcus (Fig. 8D)... "  (p. 101)
" In case PGC-R, the FB injection was centered in area TLO and involved the adjacent part of area THO (Fig. 10A). " (p. 105)
" In another case, PGF-L, an injection of FB (not illustrated) was centered in area TH..." (p. 101)

@Methods.Comments:
Citation: " To understand the overall direct hippocampal projections to the temporal lobe, tritiated amino acid injections were made into different parts  of the HF in one hemisphere in each of the 18 rhesus monkeys.
The injection sites from ten cases showing temporal lobe projections are mapped on a flattened reconstruction of the HF in Fig. 3A.
These positive injections covered different rostrocaudal levels of CA1Â´, CA1, prosubiculum, and subiculum.
In some of these cases, the injection also involved the overlapping DG, CA4, or CA3 subfields, but this is not illustrated on this two-dimensional map, because, in the other eight cases, in which the isotope injections were limited to parts of the DG, CA4, CA3, or CA2 subfields, no temporal lobe cortical projections were observed. " 
 p. 976 )

@Injections.Citation: " In case BMV-R, an injection of 30 [micro] Ci was centered in the subiculum in the posterior body of the HF " (p. 99)

"To understand the overall direct hippocampal projections to the  temporal lobe, tritiated amino acid injections were made into different parts of the HF in one hemisphere in each of 18 rhesus monkeys. The injection sites from ten cases showing temporal projections are mapped on a flattened reconstruction of the HF in Figure 3A. These positive injections covered different rostrocaudal levels of CA1Â´, CA1, prosubiculum, and subiculum. In some of these cases, the injections also involved the overlapping DG, CA4, or CA3 subfields, but this is not illustrated on this two-dimensional map, because, in the other eight cases, in which the isotope injections were limited to parts of the DG, CA4, CA3, or CA2 subfields, no temporal lobe cortical projections were observed." (p. 97)

publication.title: Organization of direct hippocampal efferent projections to the cerebral cortex of the rhesus monkey: Projections from CA1, prosubiculum, and subiculum to the temporal lobe
publication.abstract: This study investigates direct hippocampal efferent projections to the temporal lobe of the rhesus monkey. Tritiated amino acid injections were placed into the hippocampal formation to identify terminal fields, and complementary fluorescent retrograde tracer injections were placed into the cortex to identify the cells of origin. Tritiated amino acid injections into CA1, prosubicular, or subicular subfields produced anterograde label over parts of the parahippocampal gyrus and temporal pole. Injections of fluorescent retrograde tracers demonstrated that these projections originate from longitudinal strips of neurons that occupy part of the CA1 subfield as well as from strips of neurons in adjacent prosubicular and subicular subfields. Thus, an injection into area TH of the posterior parahippocampal gyrus labeled neurons in a longitudinal strip of proximal CA1 (i.e., near CA2) as well as a strip in the subiculum; injections into areas TF, TL, 35, or Pro labeled neurons in a longitudinal strip of distal CA1 (i.e., near the prosubiculum) as well as one in the prosubiculum; and an injection into area TFO labeled neurons in a longitudinal strip in the middle of CA1. These strips of neurons extended longitudinally throughout the entire rostrocaudal length of the hippocampus. These results demonstrate that, in the monkey, CA1 projections to cortex arise topographically from longitudinally oriented strips of neurons that occupy only a part of the transverse extent of CA1 but that cover most of the anteroposterior extent of the hippocampus. Thus, in the monkey, CA1 is not a single uniform entity and may have a unique role as a source of direct hippocampal projections to the cerebral cortex.
